fileDesc.extent: Approx. 45 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 28 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

availability.p: To the extent possible under law, the Text Creation Partnership has waived all copyright and related or neighboring rights to this keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above, according to the terms of the CC0 1.0 Public Domain Dedication (http://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/). This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

keywords.term: Albemarle, George Monck, -- Duke of, 1608-1670 -- Death and burial.

figure.p: The Order and Ceremonies VÅ¿ed for, and at THE SOLEMN INTERMENT OF The most High, Mighty and most Noble Prince GEORGE DUKE OF ALBEMARLE Earle of Torrington, Baron Monck of Potheridge, Beauchampe and Teyes, Captaine General of his Maties: Forces, Gentleman of his Maties: Bedchamber, one of the Lords of his Maties: most Honorable Privy Council, and Knight of the most Noble Order of the Garter A.o. 1670
Collected by Francis Sandford Gent Rouge-Dragon, one of His Maties: Officers at Armes; and Published by His Maties: especiall Command.

div.head: The Order and Ceremonies uÅ¿ed for the Solemn Interment of the MoÅ¿t High, Mighty, and MoÅ¿t Noble Prince, GEORGE late Duke of Albemarle, Earl of Torrington, Baron Monck of Poutheridge, Beauchampe, and Teyes, Captain General of His MajeÅ¿ties Forces, Gentleman of His MajeÅ¿ties Bedchamber, One of the Lords of His MajeÅ¿ties moÅ¿t Honorable Privy Council, and Knight of the MoÅ¿t Noble Order of the Garter, in the Year of our Lord 1670.
div.p:
UPon the Third day of January, An. 1669. His Grace GEORGE Duke of Albemarle, departed this Mortal Life, at his Lodgings in the Cockpit, at Whitehal; and the Å¿ame day Mr. WilliamÅ¿on (by command from the Lord Arlington, Principal Secretary of State) wrote to Sir Edward Walker Knight, Garter, Principal King of Arms, Å¿ignifying, That His MajeÅ¿ty was reÅ¿olved to pay all the Honors and ReÅ¿pects imaginable, to the memory of the Lord General deceaÅ¿ed; and that He had commanded Å¿ome of the Lords of the Council, to conÅ¿ider of fitting Solemnities for his Funeral; and to that end, That he Å¿hould prepare what he thought fit to offer to His MajeÅ¿ty, and their LordÅ¿hips. Whereupon MaÅ¿ter Garter, with Å¿ome of the Officers of Arms, attended His MajeÅ¿ty in the Council-Chamber, on the Eighth day of January following, where was preÅ¿ent
HIS MAJESTY.
His Royal HighneÅ¿s.
The Lord Steward.
The Lord Chamberlain.
The Earl of Sandwich.
The Earl of CarliÅ¿le.
The Earl of Craven.
The Lord Arlington.
The Lord AÅ¿hley.
Mr. Secretary Trevor.
Sir John Duncomb.

There they preÅ¿ented to His MajeÅ¿ty Å¿everal PreÅ¿idents, one whereof His MajeÅ¿ty having approved and made choice of to be followed, Did then give directions in Å¿everal particulars, relating to the Rooms, to be prepared at SommerÅ¿et-HouÅ¿e, where the Body was to Lye in State for Å¿ome time.

After this, the Lord Chamberlain directed Å¿everal Warrants to the Earl of Sandwich. MaÅ¿ter of the Great Wardrobe, for the furniÅ¿hing Three Rooms at SommerÅ¿et-HouÅ¿e; for the placing the Effigies there in State; for the covering and adorning the HerÅ¿e at WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter; for EÅ¿cucheons, Shields, Banners, Bannarols, &c. All which were to be delivered to Mr. Garter, or to Å¿uch perÅ¿ons as he Å¿hould appoint.

The Duke of Buckingham, MaÅ¿ter of the HorÅ¿e, did alÅ¿o Å¿end a Warrant to the Earl of Sandwich, for providing and furniÅ¿hing a Chariot, and for coverings of Black Velvet for the Chariot and HorÅ¿es, &c.
Another Warrant was Å¿ent by the Lord Chamberlain to Dr. Wren, Surveyor of the Works, to prepare a Frame of Timber; for a HerÅ¿e to be Å¿et up in WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter.
As alÅ¿o a Warrant to the Earl of Sandwich, to provide Gowns and Hoods, and other Mourning, for the Lords, Gentry, and other PerÅ¿ons, who were to officiate at the Å¿aid Funeral.

div.head: The Three Rooms at SommerÅ¿et-HouÅ¿e were furniÅ¿hed in manner following;
div.p: THe FirÅ¿t Room was hung with Bays from top to bottom, adorned with EÅ¿cucheons, and furniÅ¿hed with Sconces, and Wax-Candles unlighted; and Formes placed about it, covered with Bays.

The Second was hung with Cloath, adorned with EÅ¿cucheons, and furniÅ¿hed with Sconces and Candles, unlighted, the Forms about it covered with Cloath; at the upper end, a Haute-paÅ¿s floored with Bays, a Canopy of Black Velvet, the Vallance Fringed, the Pendant within half a yard of the Ground; a MajeÅ¿ty-EÅ¿cucheon of Taffata, a Black Velvet Chair with Arms, and a FootÅ¿tool.

The Third Room was hung with Velvet, floored with Bays, adorned with EÅ¿cucheons, and Black Sconces, with White Wax Tapers, and at the upper end upon a Haute-paÅ¿s, a Bed of State of Black Velvet was placed with Black Plumes at the Four corners of the TeÅ¿ter; at the Head a MajeÅ¿ty-EÅ¿cucheon, and another in the midÅ¿t of the TeÅ¿ter. Upon the Bed was placed a Coffin covered with a fine Holland Å¿heet of Eight bredths, and Eight ells long, and over that, a Pall of Black Velvet of Eight bredths, and Eight yards long, and thereupon the Effigies of the Duke in a Buff-coat, and over that compleat Azure Armor with Guilt Nails, a Cravat about his Neck; his Ducal Coronet and Cap turned up with Ermine on his Head, InveÅ¿ted in his Ducal Robe of CrimÅ¿on Velvet, about his Neck a Coller of the Order and George, under the Head a CuÅ¿hion of CrimÅ¿on Velvet, with Fringe and TaÅ¿Å¿els of Gold, his Sword guirt about him, and a great CrimÅ¿on TaÅ¿Å¿ata-Scarff, fringed with Gold about his WaÅ¿te, upon his Left Leg a Garter of Blew Velvet, the Buckles and Letters of Gold, and a Guilt Truncheon in his right hand.

About Five foot diÅ¿tant from the Bed, was a Rail covered with Black Velvet, and cloÅ¿e to the inÅ¿ide of the Rail, were placed on both Å¿ides, the Bannerols, three Banners, and a Guydon, and at the Foot, the Standard, and Great Banner; between theÅ¿e on the Å¿ides, were alÅ¿o placed Twelve Black Stands, with as many Silver CandleÅ¿ticks, with large White Wax Tapers in them.

At the Bed's Feet, was a little Table covered with a Carpet of Black Velvet, and thereupon were placed the Coat of Arms, Sword, Target, Helm, and CreÅ¿t, Gantlets, and Spurs. Between the Standard and the great Banner, hung a CryÅ¿tal Branch with Twelve Sockets, and therein as many Tapers of Wax.

In this Room (the proÅ¿pect of which, I have exhibited to your view in Sculpture, in the Folio following) the Tapers were continually burning when it was expoÅ¿ed to Å¿ight, which was every day (except Sunday) during the Å¿pace of about three weeks. During which time, Forty Gentlemen in Å¿hort Mourning, all which (except five) had been Officers, gave their attendance alternately, Twenty upon a day; Four of which, waited in the FirÅ¿t Room, Six in the Second Room, and Ten. In this third Room where the Effigies lay in State, Five on one Å¿ide of the Rail of the Bed of State, and Five on the other, with their backs cloÅ¿e to the Wall, their Names and Offices were as followeth.

Three days before the Solemnity of the Funeral, the Rooms aforeÅ¿aid, were Å¿hut up; and the Evening before, the Body which had lain
there, in a private Room, in a Coffin, covered with Black Velvet, with Guilt Nails and Hinges of the Å¿ame, was privately conveyed by Water to WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter, accompanied by the Earls of Bath and Craven, Sir James Smith, and others of his Kinred, and attended by Å¿everal of his Graces DomeÅ¿ticks; where it was Interred by the BiÅ¿hop of RocheÅ¿ter, Dean of WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter, in a Vault in the North IÅ¿le of King Henry the Seventh's Chappel, made there by His MajeÅ¿ties command for that purpoÅ¿e.

Upon the Coffin was faÅ¿tned a Plate of Copper Guilt, and thereupon Engraven DepoÅ¿itum IllustriÅ¿Å¿imi Principis GEORGII DÆ²CIS ALBEMARLIAE Comitis Torringtoniae, Baronis Monck de Potheridge, Beauchamp & Teyes, Carolo 2do Regi AuguÅ¿tiÅ¿Å¿imo Ã Sanctioribus ConÅ¿iliis, nec non ab intimis Cubiculis, omnium Regis Exercituum Ducis Supremi, Inclyti Ordinis Aureae PeriÅ¿celidis Equitis, &c. Obiit WeÅ¿tmonaÅ¿terii Anno Aetatis 62. Die 3o Januarii Anno reparatae Å¿alutis humanae M.DC.LXIX.

div.head: The Proceeding to the Funeral of his Grace GEORGE, late Duke of Albemarle, &c. upon Saturday the 30th of April, An. 1670.
div.p: ABout Eleven of the Clock in the Morning, the Nobility, Gentry, and other PerÅ¿ons who were to officiate at the Funeral, met at SommerÅ¿et-houÅ¿e in the Strand; between which place, and the Abbey of WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter, the Streets were gravelled, and the Red and Blew Regiments of the Trained Bands of MiddleÅ¿ex, commanded by the Earl of Craven, were placed on both Å¿ides, who kept the paÅ¿Å¿age free from the crouds of the People. The Officers of the Å¿aid Regiments being furniÅ¿hed with CypreÅ¿s Scarffs, and their Drums covered with Black Bays, adorned with EÅ¿cucheons of the Dukes Arms. All things being in a readineÅ¿s, about Two of the Clock in the Afternoon, the Funeral then proceeded in this form following,

FirÅ¿t marched His Royal HighneÅ¿s, the Duke of York's Troop of Guards, commanded by the Right Honorable MonÅ¿ieur Blancfort, the Officers having Mourning Scarffs of CypreÅ¿s, and their Cornet, Trumpet-Banners; and Kettle-Drums covered with the Å¿ame.
Three Led HorÅ¿es.
The MarÅ¿hal Richard Llewellin.
The Kettle-Drums.
Four Trumpets.

div.p: In the next place marched His MajeÅ¿ties Regiment of Foot Guards, commanded by the Right Honorable Colonel John RuÅ¿Å¿el, with their MuÅ¿quets and Pikes in a Funeral PoÅ¿ture; the Å¿everal EnÅ¿igns furled and wrapped in CypreÅ¿s, the Officers having Mourning Scarffs of the Å¿ame, and the Drums being covered with Black Bays, adorned with EÅ¿cucheons of the defunct.

div.p: Next after the HorÅ¿e of Honor, or State, Her MajeÅ¿ties Troop of Guards, commanded by Sir Philip Howard Knight, (Brother to the Right Honorable the Earl of CarliÅ¿le) cloÅ¿ed the Rear of the Proceeding, which had this place by particular order, as having been his Grace the Defuncts own Troop of Guards, and marched in the Form following, viz.
Three Led HorÅ¿es.
The Kettle Drum.
Four Trumpets.
Sir Philip Howard Knight, Captain.

div.p: IN the Order aforeÅ¿aid, the Solemnity proceeded to the WeÅ¿t Door of WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter Abbey, where the Conductors and Poor-men in Gowns opened to the Right and Left, and made way for the Proceeding to paÅ¿s between them; Å¿o that the firÅ¿t that entred the Abbey, were Servants to the Gentry and Nobility; who alÅ¿o opening to the Right and Left, made a Guard betwixt the Chore and the WeÅ¿t Door of the Abbey; without which, the Effigies was taken out of the Chariot, and placed upon a Beer, which being carried within the Abbey Door by Mr. MaÅ¿on, Colonel Markham, Major HalÅ¿all, Colonel MolÅ¿worth, Colonel Whitley, and Sir Thomas Player Knight, (who aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ted on the Left-hand of the PerÅ¿ons who bore the Standard, Guydon, Three Banners, and Great Banner, in the Proceeding) with the help of Å¿ome that belonged to the Abbey (by reaÅ¿on of the weight of it) was there received under a Canopy of Black Velvet, with a deep Silk-fringe, and lined with Black Taffata; and thence carried to the HerÅ¿e, and placed therein.

The Supporters or Bearers of the Canopy, were Sir Stephen Fox Kt, Sir Charles Littleton Kt, Sir Walter Vane Kt, Sir John Griffith Kt, Sir Edward Brett Kt, and Sir John RobinÅ¿on Knight and Baronet (the other Six AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tants in the Proceeding, on the Right Hands of thoÅ¿e that carried the aforeÅ¿aid Standard, Guydon, Three Banners, and Great Banner.)

At the entrance into the Abbey, the Dean and Prebends in their Copes; and the Quire in their Surplices, attended and proceeded between the Great Banner, and the Officers of Arms that carried the Trophies.
When they came to the HerÅ¿e, none were permitted to enter within the outward Rail, but the PerÅ¿ons following.

list.item: FirÅ¿t, Mr. Thomas Segar Blewmantle, PurÅ¿ivant at Arms.
Sir Jeremy Smith, with the Standard.
Sir Thomas Morgan, with the Guydon.
Sir Peter Killegrew, with the Banner of Teyes.
Sir Francis Vincent, with the Banner of Beauchampe.
Sir Gilbert Talbot, with the Banner of Monk, Plantagenet, Grey, and Talbot.
Mr. Bowman, with the Carpet and CuÅ¿hion.
The Defuncts, Four Officers with white Staves.
Sir James Smith, with the Great Banner.
Sir Thomas St. George SomerÅ¿et Herald, bearing the Spurs.
Mr. Thomas Lee CheÅ¿ter Herald, with the Gantlets.
Mr. Henry St. George Richmond Herald, with the Helm and CreÅ¿t.
Mr. Elias AÅ¿hmole WindÅ¿or Herald, with the Target.
Mr. William Dugdale Norroy King of Arms, with the Sword.
Sir Edward ByÅ¿Å¿he Clarenceaux, King of Arms, with the Coat of Arms.
Sir Edward Carteret, His MajeÅ¿ties Gentleman UÅ¿her.

div.p:
Then followed the Ten Bannerols bourn by
Mr. Modyford.
Mr. Bruton.
Mr. Stukley.
Mr. Fowel.
Sir Thomas Higgons.
Mr. Hooper.
Mr. Pollard.
Sir Peter Colleton.
Mr. Prideaux.
Mr. Clarges.
Sir Edward Walker, Principal King of Arms, and Sir John Ayton, UÅ¿her of the Black Rod.
TheÅ¿e were all placed within the outward Rail.
Then the Cheif Mourner, the preÅ¿ent Duke of Albemarle, entred the inward Rail, and was placed at the Head, in a Great Chair of Black Velvet with Arms.
After him entred his Two Supporters, the Dukes of Richmond and Ormond, and Å¿ate on each Å¿ide of him, upon Stools covered with Black Velvet.

And after them his Ten AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tants, viz. The Lord Chamberlain, the Earls of Suffolk, Bridgwater, Mulgrave, Peterborough, S. Albans, Sandwich, Bath, and CarliÅ¿le, and the Lord Arlington, who Å¿ate on either Å¿ide, on the like Stools.

The laÅ¿t that entred, were the Lords Newport, Gerard of Brandon, and AÅ¿hley, and Sir Thomas Clifford, TreaÅ¿urer of His MajeÅ¿ties HouÅ¿hold, the Four Supporters of the Pall, who were Å¿eated at the Corners thereof on Stools covered with Black Velvet, within the HerÅ¿e where the Effigies was placed.

Being all Å¿eated in the order aforeÅ¿aid, The Dean of WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter read the Service appointed by the Lyturgy, and that being done, Doctor Ward, BiÅ¿hop of Salisbury, Preached the Funeral Sermon: After which, the Dean and Å¿ome of the Prebends (in their Copes) went up to the Altar, and there Å¿taid for the Offering.

div.head: The Form of the Offerings,
div.p: FirÅ¿t, Mr. Bowman went up to the Altar, and Å¿pred the Carpet, and laid the CuÅ¿hion at the Foot of the Altar. Which being done, Mr. Garter repaired to the Cheif Mourner, and attended His Grace to the Offering.

The Four Officers with their white Staves went firÅ¿t, then followed Mr. Garter, and a Gentleman UÅ¿her; after them, the Cheif Mourner between his Two Supporters, his Train bourn up by Sir Francis Leak, followed by his Ten AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tants, where he offered upon his Knee, and then returned in the Å¿ame manner.

Then Mr. Bowman rouled up the Carpet, and laid it under the CuÅ¿hion; Mr. Garter, and the Gentleman UÅ¿her did again conduct the Cheif Mourner to the Altar alone, His Train not bourn, where he did offer for HimÅ¿elf; and there Å¿tood by the Dean, at the North end of the Altar, to receive the Atchievements, Mr. Garter attending him.

In the next place Mr. Clarenceaux preceded the Dukes of Richmond and Ormond, and delivered them the Coat of Arms; who being come to the Altar, offered it, and it was received by the Dean, who preÅ¿ented it to the Cheif Mourner, and he delivered it to Mr. Garter, who laid it upon the Altar; and then Mr. Clarenceaux returned with them to their Seats.
In the Å¿ame manner, Mr. Norroy brought up the Lord Chamberlain, and the Earl of Suffolk, who in like form offered the Sword, carrying the Point upward.
Mr. WindÅ¿or, the Earls of Bridgwater and Mulgrave, who offered the Target in like manner.
Mr. Richmond, the Earls of Peterborough and S. Albans, who offered the Helm and CreÅ¿t.
Mr. CheÅ¿ter, the Earls of Sandwich and Bathe, who offered the Gantlets.
Mr. SomerÅ¿et, the Earl of CarliÅ¿le, and the Lord Arlington, who offered the Spurs.
In the next place, the Great Banner half rouled up by Mr. York, was offered by Sir James Smith in like manner.
Mr. LancaÅ¿ter likewiÅ¿e with Sir Gilbert Talbot, who offered the Banner of Monck, Plantagenet, Grey, and Talbot.
Mr. Rouge-Croix with Sir Francis Vincent, with the Banner of Beauchamp.
Mr. Rouge-Dragon with Sir Peter Killegrew, with the Banner of Teyes.
Mr. Portcullis with Sir Thomas Morgan, with the Guydon.
Mr. Blewmantle with Sir Jeremy Smith, with the Standard.
The Ten Bannerols were offered by Pairs, by thoÅ¿e that carried them (beginning with the two next to the Head of the Effigies) a PurÅ¿ivant at Arms going before every two of them.
The Trophies being thus offered, the Cheif Mourner returned to his Chair, attended by Mr. Garter and the Gentleman UÅ¿her.
Then Mr. Garter conveyed up to the Altar, the Two Supporters to the Cheif Mourner, who offered for themÅ¿elves on their Knees, and then returned to their Seats.
Mr. Clarenceaux attended the two firÅ¿t AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tants, who did alÅ¿o offer in like manner for themÅ¿elves, and Å¿o returned.
The two next did the like, attended by Mr. Norroy.
The two next attended by Mr. WindÅ¿or.
The two next attended by Mr. Richmond.
And the two next attended by Mr. CheÅ¿ter.
Then Mr. SomerÅ¿et did go to the Lords, Newport and Gerard, Two Supporters of the Pall, and attended them to the Offering in like manner.
And Mr. York attended the Lord AÅ¿hley, and Mr. TreaÅ¿urer of the HouÅ¿hold, the other Two Supporters of the Pall.
TheÅ¿e being all returned to their Seats, Mr. Garter Å¿tanding on the uppermoÅ¿t Step, going to the Altar, turned his Face towards the HerÅ¿e, and proclaimed the Defuncts Å¿tile as followeth.
div.q: THus it hath pleaÅ¿ed Almighty God, to take out of this TranÅ¿itory Life, unto His Mercy, The MoÅ¿t High, Mighty, and MoÅ¿t Noble Prince GEORGE, late Duke of Albemarle, Earl of Torrington, Baron Monck of Potheridge, Beauchamp, and Teyes. Captain General of His MajeÅ¿ties Forces, Gentleman of His MajeÅ¿ties Bedchamber, One of the Lords of His MajeÅ¿ties MoÅ¿t Honorable Privy Council, and Knight of the MoÅ¿t Noble Order of the Garter.
div.p: This being Proclaimed, the Chamberlain, Steward, TreaÅ¿urer, and Comptroller to the Defunct, brake their white Staves at the Head of the Effigies.

And then His MajeÅ¿ties Sergeant-Trumpet giving a Å¿ign to the Trumpets, that were placed over the Door going into the Quire, they immediately Sounded, and the Volleys of Shot, both of HorÅ¿e and Foot, were preÅ¿ently diÅ¿charged.

div.head: A DeÅ¿cription of the HerÅ¿e Å¿et up in the Abbey of Westminster.
div.p: IN the midÅ¿t of the CroÅ¿s of the Abbey (which is betwixt the Quire, and the Steps going up to the Altar) was erected a Ducal-HerÅ¿e; the proÅ¿pect of which, with the manner of the Effigies lying in State there, the PoÅ¿ition of the Great Banner, the Three leÅ¿Å¿er Banners, Guydon, Standard, and the Ten Bannerols, with the Å¿everal Trophies upon the Table at the Feet of the Effigies, I have exhibited in the next folio.

The length of the HerÅ¿e was Fourteen Foot, the bredth Eleven Foot, and the Rail Four Foot and a half high, the HautepaÅ¿s, upon which the Table Å¿tood, raiÅ¿ing the Floor about Six Inches from the Pavement. The Four great Pillars were Eight Å¿quare, and near Twenty Foot high, and upon their Capitals were placed the CreÅ¿ts and Supporters of the Duke. TheÅ¿e Pillars had two CourÅ¿es of Rails near the tops, unto which, both the Valence and the TeÅ¿ter were faÅ¿tned; and unto this alÅ¿o, by Å¿everal CoÅ¿ts of Timber, the Cupulo was fixed; the point of which finiÅ¿hed in a Ducal Coronet, Two Foot in Diameter, exalted Thirty Foot from the Pavement. The whole HerÅ¿e was cloathed on the outÅ¿ide with Black Velvet, GarniÅ¿hed with Å¿everal Compartments EmboÅ¿Å¿ed of the Dukes Arms, and EmbelliÅ¿hed with CreÅ¿ts, Coronets, and Scrouls with his two Motto's, viz. Fortiter, Fideliter, Foeliciter, And Cunctando ReÅ¿tituit.

It was double Valanced and Fringed, the Inner Valence and TeÅ¿ter being of Black Taffata, adorned with EÅ¿cucheons of the Å¿ame, and a MajeÅ¿ty EÅ¿cucheon within the TeÅ¿ter. There were placed within the Corners of the HerÅ¿e, alÅ¿o Four Stools of Black Velvet for the Supporters of the Pall, and it was Floored with Black Cloath.

The Rail next to the HerÅ¿e, was Twenty three Foot long, Twenty Foot and a half broad, and Three Foot and a half high: This Rail was covered with Black Cloath, and Floored with Bays, and within it Å¿ate the Cheif Mourner on a Chair with Arms of Black Velvet, and his Two Supporters and Ten AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tants on Stools of the Å¿ame; and alÅ¿o to the inÅ¿ide thereof Sockets were fixed, to receive the Staves of the Standard, Guydon, Three Banners, the Great Banner, and the Ten Bannerols.

The outermoÅ¿t Rail was covered with Black Bays, being Thirty Foot long, Twenty Å¿even Foot and a half in bredth, and Three Foot high; within which Å¿everal Forms were placed, covered alÅ¿o with Bays, and upon them Å¿ate all the Carriers of the Trophies, the Officers of Arms, the Defuncts Four Officers with White Staves, and Å¿everal other perÅ¿ons concerned.

There were PaÅ¿Å¿ages alÅ¿o of Four Foot wide, on the EaÅ¿t and WeÅ¿t Å¿ide of the Rails, and the HerÅ¿e; which were opened to lett in the reÅ¿pective PerÅ¿ons, and to give them paÅ¿Å¿age to the Offering.

figure.head: A ProÅ¿pect of the HearÅ¿e in which the Effigies of the Duke of Albemarle lay in State in the Abbey of WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter.
